Following the Board approval of the R-paper, Review of ADB’s Poverty Reduction Strategy, staff 
instructions  to  replace  the  PI/CPI  classification  with  a  new  tracking  system  are  under 
preparation, in line with para. 83 of the R-paper. 
 
 
 
 
NOTES

(ii) In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
This report was prepared by D. Maligalig, Development Indicators and Policy Research Division, 
Economics and Research Department.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the 2003 Country Programming Mission to Bhutan, the Government requested 
further  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  assistance  to  build  the  capacity  of  the  National 
Statistical  Bureau  (NSB),  formerly  the  Central  Statistical  Organization  (CSO),  the  primary 
statistical agency.  Considering that its thrust will support better policy making and formulation, 
the technical assistance (TA) was included in the pipeline in 2003.  A  Fact-Finding Mission in 
August 2004 reached an understanding with the Government on the objectives, scope, and 
implementation of the TA.1 The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The CSO, an agency under the Ministry of Planning, had benefited from two previous 
statistical capacity building assistance2 from ADB.  The two TAs put the CSO  toward the 
direction of a modern statistical system capable of providing official statistics that are consistent 
with international standards.  Technical advice and funding for survey operations enabled CSO 
to complete two household surveys that became the main data sources for social indicators and 
poverty statistics.  The compilation of a consumer price index  (CPI) and national accounts was 
also improved by shifting these series to a more recent base year and incorporating new data 
inputs.3  Data collection for CPI was expanded to cover key geographical areas, while estimates 
for national accounts were revised by including the results of the two households surveys and 
the 2000 census of agriculture.  Some of the CSO staff were also trained in compiling official 
statistics through apprenticeship programs.   
 
3.  In October 2003, the Government decided to redesignate the Ministry of Planning as a 
department under the Ministry of Finance.  The restructuring resulted in CSO becoming the 
NSB, an autonomous agency that reports to a newly created Statistical Board chaired by the 
Minister  of  Labor  and  Human  Resources,  with  deputy  secretaries  from  the  ministries  of 
agriculture, finance, health, and home affairs and Royal Monetary Authority as members.   The 
Statistical Board will be responsible for formulating policies and planning guidelines for NSB and 
all the data-producing government agencies.  NSB, in addition to its mandate as the primary 
compiler of official statistics, will also support the Board’s coordination functions.  
 
4.  To undertake the coordination functions,  NSB will have to establish  a data support 
system  that  will  systematically  store  and  disseminate  statistics  compiled  by  various  data-
producing agencies, including metadata. Moreover, NSB has to complete the shift of national 
accounts to the more recent framework — the 1993 System of National Accounts (SNA) — so 
that the current structure of the economy can be better measured.   A master sample4 that will 
use the first census of population that will be conducted in 2005 as a sampling frame will also 
have to be formulated for future household surveys.  
 
5.  While becoming autonomous is advantageous to NSB since it could now assert its 
professional independence, it also caused NSB some administrative problems that could disrupt  
its data compilation and dissemination activities.  Because the Government directed NSB to find 
another office location for its 42 technical and 12 support staff at the central office, the local area

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
6.  The TA’s goal is to strengthen the national statistical system.  The objectives are the 
following:  (i)  to  provide  support  to  the  reorganization  of  the  NSB  and  the  newly  created 
Statistical Board, (ii) to continue  enhancing the compilation of national accounts, and (iii) to 
upgrade the technical skill level of NSB’s staff. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The  TA  will  have  the  following  components:  (i)  provision  of  technical  support  and 
equipment to NSB and the Statistical Board, including the finalization of the Statistics Law; (ii) 
improvement of national accounts; and (iii) apprenticeship programs for NSB staff.  To cover 
these components, the TA will provide advisory services for statistical office management, 
national  accounts,  and  database  development.    Computing  equipment  and  software  for 
establishing a local area network will also be procured.   
 
8.  Through consultations with data-producing agencies, NSB will develop  a designated 
statistics program with the assistance of an expert.  The program will assign each category of 
official statistics to the agency that has the most suitable infrastructure to generate them.  This 
will minimize duplication of activities, ensure the timely dissemination of statistics, and optimize 
the very limited resources that the Government allocates to statistics.  The TA will also assist 
the Statistical Board in developing a 3-year statistics plan that will provide better direction for 
NSB and other relevant agencies.  A statistical database will also be developed to store and 
disseminate the designated statistics program, the metadata for each category of  statistics 
under the program, all the available time series, information regarding surveys that have been 
conducted and those that need clearance from the Statistical Board, technical papers and lists 
of publications.  Application programs will be developed to retrieve and disseminate data and 
information from the database, to generate statistical reports, and to manage and update the 
database. 
 
9.  National accounts statistics will be enhanced by the incorporation of price deflators 
formulated from the new CPI series and from the producers’ price index that will have to be 
developed, by revising estimates that would be generated from new data inputs and by initiating 
quarterly accounts.  Additional accounts as required by the 1993 SNA will also be developed to 
complete the shift from the 1968 SNA to the 1993 SNA. Special studies and small surveys will 
be conducted to facilitate the development of these accounts.  
  
10.  In  addition  to  on-the-job  and  formal  training  that  NSB  staff  will  receive  from the 
consultants, five apprenticeship programs will be supported by the TA, namely: (i) development 
of a master sample, (ii) compilation of national accounts, (iii) socioeconomic analysis of existing 
survey data,  (iv) administrative/financial, and (v) local area network administration and data 
processing.  Host statistical offices will be identified by ADB in consultation with NSB.  Such 
offices  will  be  requested  to  formulate  appropriate  programs  for  selected  NSB  staff.  
Apprenticeship on the development of a master sample will be undertaken when  population

3
data have been processed and validated so that they could be used as a sampling frame.  All 
future household surveys could then avail of the master sample to ensure the consistency of 
statistics generated from them.   
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
11.  The TA is estimated to cost $380,000 equivalent, of which $216,000 is the  foreign 
exchange cost and $164,000 equivalent is the local currency cost (Appendix 2).  ADB will 
finance, on a grant basis, $250,000 equivalent from ADB’s TA funding program, to cover the 
$216,000 foreign exchange cost and $34,000 equivalent of the local cost.  The Government of 
Bhutan will finance the balance of the local currency cost equivalent to $130,000, covering the 
cost of conducting sample surveys, paying counterpart staff salaries, making office facilities 
available, and providing other administrative overhead. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA, which is expected to begin in December 2004, will be spread over 24 months, 
with  completion  by  December  2006.  NSB  will  be  the  Executing  Agency.    Aside  from  its 
administrative functions, NSB will (i) provide counterpart staff to work with the consultants, (ii) 
seek government funding for surveys, and (iii) provide administrative and technical support to 
the consultants. 
 
13.  The  Development  Indicators  and  Policy  Research  Division  of  the  Economics  and 
Research Department (ERDI), in collaboration with  the South Asia Operations Coordination 
Division, will administer the TA. ADB will coordinate TA implementation with other funding 
agencies, particularly the World Bank and United Nations Development Programme, to reduce 
duplication  of  activities.  TA  monitoring  and  review  will  be  done  through  ADB  missions, 
correspondence including e-mail, and reports of consultants. The ERDI project officer will 
coordinate all activities of the TA and will liaise with NSB. NSB will submit an assessment report 
and recommendations for future action after completion of each major activity. 
 
14.  The TA will engage three international consultants: (i) a national accounts expert for 2 
person-months,  (ii)  a  statistics  office  management  expert  for  1  person-month, and (iii) a 
database  developer  and  programmer  for  4  person-months.  The  ERDI  project  officer  will 
coordinate the activities of the consultants. The consultants will be selected individually and will 
be engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Outline terms of 
reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
15.  The NSB management and the consultants will recommend to ADB the candidates for 
the apprenticeship programs. The selection criteria, terms, and conditions for the apprenticeship 
program  are  in  Appendix  4.  The  trainees  will  submit  in  a  report  to  NSB  and  ADB  their 
assessment of their apprenticeship program and their recommendations on how to incorporate 
what they have learned in their jobs. The Government will take the necessary steps to ensure 
that staff who participate in the apprenticeship program will return and continue working for 
NSB. 
 
16.  Durable equipment will be purchased from the TA proceeds in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines for Procurement. The equipment will be turned over to NSB upon completion of the 
TA.

IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for  Strengthening the National Statistical System Phase 2, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR INTERNATIONAL CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  National Accounts Expert (2 person-months) 
 
1.  The expert must have appropriate qualifications and extensive technical background and 
experience in compiling national accounts under the 1993 System of National Accounts (SNA). 
The expert will assist the National Statistical Bureau (NSB) in undertaking the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Incorporate revisions in the price deflators derived for the re-based consumer 
price index series; 
(ii)  Complete the missing data in calendar year 1999 for government value-added 
and expenditure using data on government expenditure fiscal year 1998/99; 
(iii)  Review the estimates and incorporate revisions when new data sets are made 
available (e.g., outputs from the trade licenses database that was developed 
under TA 3669 BHU), with emphasis on reconciling the gross domestic product  
estimates by economic activity and by expenditure; 
(iv)  Develop the producers price index; 
(v)  Continue  improving  national  accounts  by  compiling  additional  accounts 
suggested for the implementation of the 1993 SNA;  
(vi)  Review the poverty estimates generated by NSB from the 2002 Bhutan Living 
Standards Survey; and  
  (vii)  Submit a completion report to NSB and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 3 
days before the end of the consultancy. 
B.  Statistics Office Management Expert (1 person-month) 
2.  The expert must have wide experience in managing a national statistics office. The 
expert will assist NSB in undertaking the following tasks: 
(i)  Draft a designated statistics program for the statistical system that would assign 
each category of official statistics to the most suitable government agency; 
(ii)  Formulate a 3-year development plan for the statistical system;  
(iii)  Assist NSB in finalizing the draft Statistics Law for endorsement of the Statistics 
Board including coordination with the law ministry for review; and  
(iv)  Submit a completion report to NSB and  ADB 3 days before the end of the 
consultancy.  
C.  Database Developer and Programmer (4 person-months) 
 
3.   The expert must have a strong background in developing statistical databases and in 
application programming, especially for web-enabled databases and for generating statistical 
reports.  The expert will perform the following tasks:

10  Appendix 3 
 
(i)  Implement a suitable data schema, including a standard classification system, for 
the high-priority requirements of the Statistical Board; 
(ii)  Develop application programs for retrieval, report generation, and management 
of the statistical database;  
(iii)  Provide formal and on-the-job training to NSB and other concerned government 
agencies’ staff; and 
(iv)  Submit a completion report to NSB and ADB 3 days before the end of the 
consultancy.

Appendix 4  11
THE APPRENTICESHIP PROGRAMS 
1.  There are five planned apprenticeship programs in this technical assistance, namely:  (i) 
development of a master sample, (ii) compilation of national accounts, (iii) socioeconomic 
analysis  of  existing  survey  data,  (iv)  administrative/financial,  and  (v)  local  area  network 
administration  and  data  processing.    The  trainees  are  expected  to  produce  the  following 
outputs, respectively: (i) a master sample, (ii) improved methodology for compiling national 
accounts, (iii) technical papers on a chosen subject, (iv) a system for the library and financial 
administration of this TA, and (v) local area administration and data processing manuals.  
 
A.  Selection Criteria 
2.  Trainees must have the following qualifications: 
 
(i)  Be a regular staff of the National Statistical Bureau (NSB) and must have worked 
at NSB for at least 1 year; and 
 
(ii)  Have  at  least  6  months  formal  training  in  basic  statistics,  or  equivalent 
experience.  
 
B.  Terms and Conditions 
3.  The trainees must agree to the following terms and conditions: 
 
(i)  The trainees will undergo an apprenticeship program in an institution selected by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and NSB; 
 
(ii)  The apprenticeship program will be funded from this technical assistance; 
 
(iii)  The trainees must complete the expected output as defined in para. 1 of this 
Appendix; 
 
(iv)  After the apprenticeship program, the trainees must continue to work at NSB for 
at least 3 years;  
 
(v)  The  trainee  must  provide  a  comprehensive  documentation  of  the  training 
materials that were obtained from the apprenticeship program and conduct a 
seminar for other NSB staff on what has been learned; and 
 
(vi)  Each trainee must submit to ADB and NSB a report of how he or she plans to 
integrate the technology learned from the apprenticeship program into the NSB 
work program.
